title: My Lab Journal
text: Welcome to my online portfolio. I’m Miguel, a passionate Industrial Engineer from the esteemed Politécnica de Madrid, in Spain. Currently, I’m expanding my horizons as an Erasmus student at TUHH, where I’m delving into the dynamic world of Data Science. On this website, you’ll have the opportunity to follow my journey through the Data Science course, as I share my progress and insights step by step. Enjoy your visit!

title: My Lab Journal
section: What are you going to see?
text:
What are you going to see?
In the top menu, you will find the menu, where there are different sections:

Home: This is the main screen.
Journal: This is in turn subdivided into:

01: Tidyverse
02: Data Acquisition
03: Data Wrangling
04: Data Visualization

Class Notes: Any contribution that I have seen interesting to contribute.
Links: Different interesting links that have been used.

title: Class Notes
text:
IMPORTANT: You can delete everything in here and start fresh. You might want to start by not deleting anything above this line until you know what that stuff is doing.
This is an .qmd file. It is plain text with special features. Any time you write just like this, it will be compiled to normal text in the website. If you put a # in front of your text, it will create a top level-header.

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Codeknitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE)

setwd("C:/Users/migue/Desktop/Hamburg/TUHH/ss24-bdsb-miguelp98/01_raw_data")
# Cargar librerías necesarias
library(tidyverse)
library(vroom)
library(data.table)
library(tictoc)

# Definir los tipos de columnas para cada archivo

# assignee.tsv
col_types_assignee <- list(
  id = col_character(),
  type = col_character(),
  organization = col_character()
)

# patent.tsv
col_types_patent <- list(
  id = col_character(),
  date = col_date("%Y-%m-%d"),
  num_claims = col_integer()
)

# patent_assignee.tsv
col_types_patent_assignee <- list(
  patent_id = col_character(),
  assignee_id = col_character()
)

# uspc.tsv
col_types_uspc <- list(
  patent_id = col_character(),
  mainclass_id = col_character(),
  sequence = col_integer()
)

# Importar los datos

# assignee.tsv
assignee_tbl <- vroom(
  file       = "assignee.tsv", 
  delim      = "\t", 
  col_types  = col_types_assignee,
  na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)
setDT(assignee_tbl)

# patent.tsv
patent_tbl <- vroom(
  file       = "patent.tsv", 
  delim      = "\t", 
  col_types  = col_types_patent,
  na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)
setDT(patent_tbl)

# patent_assignee.tsv
patent_assignee_tbl <- vroom(
  file       = "patent_assignee.tsv", 
  delim      = "\t", 
  col_types  = col_types_patent_assignee,
  na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)
setDT(patent_assignee_tbl)

# uspc.tsv
uspc_tbl <- vroom(
  file       = "uspc.tsv", 
  delim      = "\t", 
  col_types  = col_types_uspc,
  na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)
setDT(uspc_tbl)

# Renombrar columnas para consistencia
setnames(patent_assignee_tbl, old = c("patent_id", "assignee_id"), new = c("id", "assignee_id"))
setnames(uspc_tbl, old = "patent_id", new = "id")

# Combinar los datos paso a paso
combined_data <- merge(patent_tbl, patent_assignee_tbl, by = "id")
combined_data <- merge(combined_data, assignee_tbl, by.x = "assignee_id", by.y = "id")
combined_data <- merge(combined_data, uspc_tbl, by = "id")

# Visualizar una muestra de los datos combinados
combined_data %>% glimpse()

#> Rows: 802,177
#> Columns: 8
#> $ id           <chr> "8621662", "8621663", "8621663", "8621666", "8621666", "8…
#> $ assignee_id  <chr> "org_aTMUEAbUvQuADfnSfudQ", "org_FfZ2sonhh4RvKY8vYp2B", "…
#> $ date         <date> 2014-01-07, 2014-01-07, 2014-01-07, 2014-01-07, 2014-01-…
#> $ num_claims   <int> 11, 6, 6, 7, 7, 21, 21, 21, 21, 21, 19, 19, 19, 19, 8, 15…
#> $ type         <chr> "2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "2…
#> $ organization <chr> "Hamilton Sundstrand Space Systems International, Inc.", …
#> $ mainclass_id <chr> "2", "2", "351", "2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "2", …
#> $ sequence     <int> 0, 0, 1, 0, 1, 0, 1, 3, 2, 4, 0, 2, 1, 3, 0, 0, 2, 3, 1, …

Code# Contar las patentes por organización
patent_count <- combined_data[, .N, by = organization][order(-N)][1:10]

# Mostrar el resultado
print(patent_count)

#>                                    organization     N
#>                                          <char> <int>
#>  1: International Business Machines Corporation 19056
#>  2:               Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd. 14523
#>  3:                      Canon Kabushiki Kaisha  9467
#>  4:                            Sony Corporation  8372
#>  5:                       QUALCOMM Incorporated  7322
#>  6:                       Microsoft Corporation  7195
#>  7:                    Kabushiki Kaisha Toshiba  6957
#>  8:                                 Google Inc.  6082
#>  9:                         LG Electronics Inc.  5694
#> 10:                       Panasonic Corporation  5641

Code# Filtrar patentes de agosto de 2014 y contar por organización
august_patents <- combined_data[format(date, "%Y-%m") == "2014-08", .N, by = organization][order(-N)][1:10]

# Mostrar el resultado
print(august_patents)

#>                                    organization     N
#>                                          <char> <int>
#>  1: International Business Machines Corporation  1810
#>  2:               Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd.  1223
#>  3:                       Microsoft Corporation   779
#>  4:                      Canon Kabushiki Kaisha   772
#>  5:                            Sony Corporation   596
#>  6:                       QUALCOMM Incorporated   591
#>  7:                                 Google Inc.   566
#>  8:                    Kabushiki Kaisha Toshiba   544
#>  9:        Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., Ltd.   514
#> 10:                                  Apple Inc.   501

Code# Filtrar datos y contar las principales clases tecnológicas
top_tech_sectors <- combined_data[, .N, by = mainclass_id][order(-N)][1:5]

# Mostrar el resultado
print(top_tech_sectors)

#>    mainclass_id     N
#>          <char> <int>
#> 1:          257 41500
#> 2:          455 29419
#> 3:          370 25628
#> 4:          438 20372
#> 5:          709 18345

title: Tidyverse
text:
Tidyverse is a collection of essential R packages for data science. The packages under the tidyverse umbrella help us in performing and interacting with the data. There are a whole host of things you can do with your data, such as subsetting, transforming, visualizing, etc.

In this section we will study the sales of bikes through bikes stores in Germany. We will work with a database provided by Canyon
After clean all the data we are showing two different tasks.

Task 1: Revenue by State
In the column bar plot you can see the Revenue by State . As we can see the state of North Rhine-Westphalia is the one that has highest Revenue.

It is recommended to expand the pictures to see them properly.









Task 2: Sales by location and year
In the image below we are separating the images for each state in each year. This will give us 12 different bar charts.

title: Data Acquisition
text:
Data acquisition is the process of converting real-world signals to the digital domain for display, storage, and analysis.

In this section we will work with two concepts API and Scraping. In the Task 1 we will work with the API and can get the weather of Madrid. For that, we will use the following link Open Weather. In the Task 2 we will scrape the model and prices from the page Rose Bikes.
Task 1: Using API to get Madrid’s temperature








Task 2: Scraping to get prices from different bike models
The idea is to print the model and price of the next picture:









Model
Price



BACKROAD AL
1.999,00 €


BACKROAD
2.999,00 €


BACKROAD LIMITED
4.449,00 €

title: Links
text:
R is a free open-source programming language that can be used for statistical analysis, data-simulation, graphing, and lots of other stuff. Another free program is R-studio, that provides a nice graphic interface for R. Download R first, then download R-studio. Both can run on PCs, Macs or Linux. Students will be learning R in the stats labs using the lab manual .




Google is great, Google your problem
Stackoverflow is great, google will often take you there because someone has already asked your question, and someone else has answered, usually many people have answered your question many ways.
